description: From Middle English dwale (“stupor; deception; delusion, evil”), from Old English dwala, dwola (“error, heresy; doubt; madman, deceiver, heretic”) and Old Norse dvala (“sleep, stupor”).

entries.meaning: Belladonna or a similar soporific plant.
examples: Beneath and around the clumps of ragged moss-grown elder and hoary stunted whitethorn (...) rise thickets of tall nettles and rank hemlock, concealing the deadly but alluring dwale —

entries.meaning: (archaic) A sleeping-potion, especially one made from belladonna.
(heraldry) Sable or black (when the colors are blazoned as plants).

description: From Middle English dwalen, from Old English dwalian, from Proto-Germanic *dwalōną, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰwelH- (“to make turbid”).

verbs.description: dwale (third-person singular simple present dwales, present participle dwaling, simple past and past participle dwaled)
